Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: A home loan repayment is due in two months, and the step-parent needs to prepare for it
Expectation2: Offer help or support when asked
Situation2: An acquaintance asks for a recommendation on a good restaurant in the area.
Story:
I sat at the kitchen table, bills spread out before me, the looming home loan repayment weighing heavily on my mind. As a step-parent, I felt the pressure to keep everything afloat, to make sure my partner and stepchild never felt the sting of financial instability. Every dollar counted, and I was already calculating what we could cut back on to make the next payment. My phone buzzed—a message from Mark, an old acquaintance from work. “Hey, I’m in your neighborhood tonight. Any chance you could recommend a good restaurant? Maybe even join me for dinner?” 

I knew Mark was going through a rough patch and probably needed someone to talk to. As an acquaintance, I felt obligated to be supportive, to offer my time and a listening ear. But the thought of spending money on dinner, even just for myself, made my stomach twist. I wanted to help, but I also needed to protect my family’s finances. The expectations from both sides pulled at me, and I sat there, phone in hand, torn between being the reliable step-parent and the supportive acquaintance, unsure which role to answer first.
